In this example, we'll create a button with an `aria-label` attribute, which is used to provide an accessible name for the button when the button's text content is not sufficient to describe its purpose. ```html Button with ARIA Label Example ``` In this example, we have a button with an image of a shopping cart icon. Since the button doesn't have any text content, we use the `aria-label` attribute to provide a meaningful name for screen readers, in this case "Add to cart". When a user with a screen reader interacts with this button, they will hear "Add to cart" instead of just hearing "button". Now let's look at an example using `aria-labelledby`: ```html Button with ARIA Labelledby Example

Shopping Cart

``` In this example, we have a button with the text "Clear Cart" and a heading with the text "Shopping Cart". We use the `aria-labelledby` attribute on the button to reference the `id` of the heading element. This will cause screen readers to announce the button as "Shopping Cart Clear Cart" instead of just "Clear Cart", providing more context to the user about the purpose of the button.
